Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Situation2: They handle a busy checkout with a long queue during peak hours.
Story: I could feel my phone buzzing in my apron pocket as I scanned groceries, the beeping of the register barely masking the anxiety building in my chest. The line stretched down the aisle, customers shifting impatiently, and I forced a smile as I handed change to the next person. My boyfriend’s name flashed on my screen again—another message, probably about the argument we’d had this morning. We’d been fighting all week about money, and I knew he expected me to text back, to help us work things out. But right now, my manager was watching, and every customer expected me to be quick and accurate. My hands trembled as I counted bills, my mind split between the register and the words I wanted to say to him. I wanted to fix things, to show him I cared, but I couldn’t risk making a mistake at work. The pressure from both sides squeezed me, and I felt trapped, unable to be the girlfriend he needed or the cashier my job demanded.
